DOC.HEAD: Faint 1992 Rumblings Heard in Iowa
With AM-First Stirrings Bjt
DOC.TEXT: When the phone rang the other day in Joe Shanahan's office, he wasn't surprised to find an aide to Sen. Lloyd Bentsen on the line, looking to trade gossip about a political consultant. ``I have a lot of newfound friends in Bentsen's office,'' said Shanahan, spokesman for the Iowa Democratic Party. Bentsen, the Texas senator who was the Democrats' vice presidential nominee in 1988, isn't the only prominent Democrat keeping tabs on Iowa, the state with the first caucuses in the presidential sweepstakes. Those mulling a run for the White House in 1992 _ or consultants looking to align themselves with a presidential campaign _ are keeping an eye on 1990 elections in Iowa, which has tough contests for governor and Senate. ``Anybody who is looking down the road to 1992 has a good reason to visit the state,'' said Phil Roeder, political director for Democratic Sen. Tom Harkin, who is being challenged next year by Republican Rep. Tom Tauke. Indeed, many potential 1992 Democratic candidates have been stopping in Iowa of late. New Jersey Sen. Bill Bradley came to raise money for Harkin, and activists on hand said there was some informal talk about the possibility of a Bradley presidential bid. Bentsen was the featured speaker at the state Democratic Party's annual fund-raiser this past fall, denying any interest in running for president in 1992 but nonetheless taking time to talk to reporters about his ideas for national election strategy. House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, winner of the 1988 Iowa caucuses, visited recently, and Jesse Jackson was on hand the day after the last election and since to speak at a funeral. ``Those people have been out here under the auspices of helping the Democratic Party,'' said Shanahan. ``You can read whatever you want into that, but we're glad they're here.'' And, although President Bush is expected to be unopposed for the Republican nomination should he seek re-election, Democrats haven't had the state to themselves. Texas Sen. Phil Gramm and television evangelist Pat Robertson, an unsuccessful 1988 GOP presidential candidate who finished second in Iowa last year behind Sen. Bob Dole, have dropped in for quick visits, fueling speculation they might be looking down the road to 1996. Iowa political operatives aren't surprised at the early attention; presidential candidates who have done well here often began their caucus campaigns a year or more before the vote. Said Roeder: ``If we get by with 12 to 15 hours of down time between the 1990 elections and the beginning of the 1992 caucuses, that will be a pretty liberal amount of time.''
